metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: Model the acceleration of particles in a particle accelerator (including synchrotrons) as uniform circular motion (limited to linear acceleration by a uniform electric field and direction change by a uniform magnetic field)

electric_field_acceleration.name: Electric Field Acceleration
electric_field_acceleration.correct: Uniform electric fields accelerate charged particles in straight lines. The kinetic energy gained equals the work done by the field: ½mv² = qV.

changes direction.error: Electric fields change speed, not direction (when parallel to motion).
changes direction.fix: Uniform electric fields apply constant force → constant acceleration → speed change in a straight line.
changes direction.action: Draw force vectors on a charge between parallel plates. Force is parallel to field.

constant speed.error: A net force causes acceleration, not constant speed.
constant speed.fix: F = qE produces acceleration a = qE/m. Speed increases.
constant speed.action: Apply F = ma. If F ≠ 0, then a ≠ 0, so v changes.

circular motion.error: That's magnetic fields, not electric fields.
circular motion.fix: Electric fields → linear acceleration. Magnetic fields → circular path.
circular motion.action: Remember: E-field = speed change. B-field = direction change.

persistent.gap: You're confusing the roles of electric and magnetic fields in accelerators.
persistent.action: Make a table: Electric field → linear acceleration, speed change. Magnetic field → circular path, direction change.

energy_transformation_accelerator.name: Energy Transformation in Accelerators
energy_transformation_accelerator.correct: Work done by the electric field (W = qV) transforms electrical potential energy into kinetic energy (½mv²).

qV = mv².error: Missing the ½ factor in kinetic energy.
qV = mv².fix: Kinetic energy is ½mv², not mv².
qV = mv².action: Write out KE = ½mv². The ½ comes from integration of F = ma.

qV = ½mv.error: Wrong dimension. mv is momentum, not energy.
qV = ½mv.fix: Energy = ½mv². Momentum = mv. Different quantities.
qV = ½mv.action: Check units: qV is in Joules. ½mv² is in Joules. ½mv is in kg·m/s.

V = ½mv².fix: Work done = qV. Different charges gain different energy from same voltage.
V = ½mv².action: Compare electron and proton through same V. Same qV but different speeds.

persistent.gap: You're not applying energy conservation correctly in accelerators.
persistent.action: Practice: qV = ½mv². Solve for v given q, V, m. Do five examples.

electron_gun_function.name: Electron Gun Function
electron_gun_function.formula: Heated cathode → free electrons → accelerated by E-field
electron_gun_function.correct: An electron gun uses a heated cathode to release electrons, which are then accelerated by a uniform electric field between parallel plates.

magnetic field accelerates electrons.error: Magnetic fields change direction, not speed.
magnetic field accelerates electrons.fix: Electric field between plates provides the accelerating force.
magnetic field accelerates electrons.action: F = qE gives acceleration. F = qvB is always perpendicular to v, so no speed change.

cold cathode releases electrons.fix: Heating the cathode gives electrons enough energy to escape the metal.
cold cathode releases electrons.action: Research: thermionic emission. Electrons need thermal energy to overcome work function.

electrons attracted to cathode.error: Electrons are repelled by the negative cathode.
electrons attracted to cathode.fix: Cathode is negative. Electrons (negative) are repelled toward positive anode.
electrons attracted to cathode.action: Draw the electron gun. Label charges. Like charges repel.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how electron guns produce and accelerate electrons.
persistent.action: Draw and label an electron gun: heated cathode, anode, electric field direction, electron path.

magnetic_force_perpendicular.name: Magnetic Force Perpendicular to Velocity
magnetic_force_perpendicular.correct: The magnetic force is always perpendicular to both velocity and magnetic field, so it changes direction but not speed.

parallel to velocity.error: If F were parallel to v, it would change speed. But F ⊥ v in magnetic fields.
parallel to velocity.fix: Right-hand rule: F is perpendicular to both v and B.
parallel to velocity.action: Use right-hand palm rule. Thumb = v, fingers = B, palm = F. F can't be along v.

parallel to magnetic field.error: Force is perpendicular to the field, not parallel.
parallel to magnetic field.fix: F = qv × B. Cross product is perpendicular to both inputs.
parallel to magnetic field.action: Right-hand rule gives force direction perpendicular to both v and B.

in the direction of motion.error: That would cause acceleration. Magnetic force only deflects.
in the direction of motion.fix: F ⊥ v means no component of force along direction of motion. No work done.
in the direction of motion.action: Work = F·d·cos(θ). When θ = 90°, cos(90°) = 0. No work → no speed change.

persistent.gap: You don't understand why magnetic fields can't change speed.
persistent.action: Key insight: F ⊥ v always. Work = 0 when force is perpendicular to displacement. No work = no KE change.

right_hand_rule.name: Right-Hand Rule for Magnetic Force
right_hand_rule.formula: Thumb = v, Fingers = B, Palm = F (positive charge)
right_hand_rule.correct: Use right-hand palm rule: thumb points in velocity direction, fingers in B direction, palm pushes in force direction for positive charges.

palm gives velocity.fix: Thumb = velocity, Fingers = B-field, Palm = Force on positive charge.
palm gives velocity.action: Practice: point thumb right (v), fingers into page (B), palm pushes up (F).

fingers give force.fix: Palm gives force direction. Fingers align with magnetic field.

works same for negative charges.error: Negative charges experience force in opposite direction.
works same for negative charges.fix: For electrons: use right-hand rule then reverse the force direction.
works same for negative charges.action: Or point thumb opposite to electron velocity, then palm gives electron force.

persistent.gap: You haven't mastered the right-hand rule.
persistent.action: Practice 10 examples. For each: given v and B, find F. Then reverse for electrons.

circular_motion_magnetic.name: Circular Motion in Magnetic Field
circular_motion_magnetic.correct: When a charged particle moves perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field, the magnetic force provides centripetal force, causing uniform circular motion.

spiral motion.error: Spiral occurs if there's a velocity component parallel to B. Perpendicular motion gives circles.
spiral motion.fix: When v ⊥ B completely, motion is circular. Speed stays constant.
spiral motion.action: For spirals, v must have a component along B. That component is unaffected.

parabolic path.error: Parabolas occur in uniform gravitational or electric fields, not magnetic.
parabolic path.fix: Magnetic force is always ⊥ to velocity → constant magnitude → circular path.
parabolic path.action: Compare: gravity → parabola, electric field (⊥ to v) → parabola, magnetic → circle.

straight line.error: Only if v is parallel to B. Perpendicular velocity curves.
straight line.fix: When v ⊥ B, F = qvB deflects the particle continuously into a circle.
straight line.action: If v ∥ B, then F = 0 (no deflection). If v ⊥ B, maximum deflection.

persistent.gap: You don't understand why magnetic fields cause circular motion.
persistent.action: Key: F ⊥ v always, constant magnitude. This is the definition of centripetal force → circular path.

radius_formula.name: Radius of Circular Path
radius_formula.correct: The radius of circular motion in a magnetic field is r = mv/qB. Larger mass or speed increases radius; larger charge or field decreases it.

r = qB/mv.fix: r = mv/qB. Mass and velocity are on top.
r = qB/mv.action: Derive: qvB = mv²/r → r = mv/qB. Check dimensions: kg·m/s ÷ (C·T) = m.

r = mv²/qB.error: Extra v factor. It's mv, not mv².
r = mv²/qB.fix: From qvB = mv²/r, cancel one v to get qB = mv/r → r = mv/qB.
r = mv²/qB.action: Redo the algebra: start with qvB = mv²/r, solve for r.

r = qvB/m.error: This has wrong structure. Should be mv on top.
r = qvB/m.fix: r = mv/qB. More momentum (mv) = larger radius.
r = qvB/m.action: Physical intuition: faster or heavier particles are harder to bend → larger r.

persistent.gap: You need to memorise and understand r = mv/qB.
persistent.action: Derive it yourself three times. Then use it to calculate r for different particles.

radius_dependencies.name: Factors Affecting Radius
radius_dependencies.formula: r ∝ m, r ∝ v, r ∝ 1/q, r ∝ 1/B
radius_dependencies.correct: Radius increases with mass and speed; radius decreases with larger charge or stronger magnetic field.

larger B increases r.error: Stronger field bends particles more tightly → smaller radius.
larger B increases r.fix: r = mv/qB. B is in the denominator. Larger B → smaller r.
larger B increases r.action: Think: stronger magnet = tighter curve. That's smaller radius.

larger q increases r.error: Larger charge experiences larger force → tighter curve → smaller radius.
larger q increases r.fix: r = mv/qB. q is in the denominator. Larger q → smaller r.
larger q increases r.action: Compare proton (q = e) and alpha particle (q = 2e). Alpha bends more tightly.

larger m decreases r.error: Heavier particles are harder to deflect → larger radius.
larger m decreases r.fix: r = mv/qB. m is in the numerator. Larger m → larger r.
larger m decreases r.action: Physical intuition: heavy objects have more inertia, resist bending.

persistent.gap: You're not applying the radius formula correctly.
persistent.action: Write r = mv/qB. For each variable, determine: numerator or denominator? Then state effect on r.

synchrotron_principle.name: Synchrotron Operating Principle
synchrotron_principle.formula: Electric fields accelerate, magnetic fields steer
synchrotron_principle.correct: Synchrotrons use electric fields in straight sections to increase particle speed, and magnetic fields in curved sections to bend particles into a circular path.

magnetic fields accelerate.error: Magnetic fields can't change speed. They only change direction.
magnetic fields accelerate.fix: Electric fields provide acceleration. Magnetic fields provide steering.
magnetic fields accelerate.action: Synchrotron layout: straight sections (E-field, speed up) + curved sections (B-field, bend).

electric fields bend path.error: Electric fields cause straight-line acceleration (when E ∥ v).
electric fields bend path.fix: To bend a relativistic particle, you need magnetic force F = qvB.
electric fields bend path.action: Why magnetic? Electric force F = qE is limited. Magnetic force F = qvB scales with v.

single field type used.error: Both field types are essential for different functions.
single field type used.fix: E-field: increase energy. B-field: maintain circular path.
single field type used.action: Draw synchrotron schematic: label E-field regions and B-field regions.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the complementary roles of E and B fields in synchrotrons.
persistent.action: Memorise: E-field = energy boost (linear). B-field = path control (circular).

synchrotron_radius_constant.name: Maintaining Constant Radius in Synchrotrons
synchrotron_radius_constant.formula: As v increases, B must increase to keep r constant
synchrotron_radius_constant.correct: In a synchrotron, as particles speed up, the magnetic field strength is increased to keep the radius constant (r = mv/qB).

radius increases with speed.error: That's true for fixed B. In synchrotrons, B is adjusted to keep r fixed.
radius increases with speed.fix: r = mv/qB. To keep r constant when v increases, B must also increase.
radius increases with speed.action: Rearrange: B = mv/qr. If r is fixed and v increases, B must increase.

B stays constant.error: Constant B with increasing v would cause increasing radius.
B stays constant.fix: Synchrotrons have variable B. As particles accelerate, magnets strengthen.
B stays constant.action: Look up 'synchrotron' design. Key feature: synchronized increasing magnetic field.

particles slow down.error: Synchrotrons accelerate particles to higher speeds.
particles slow down.fix: Electric field sections add energy. Particles get faster each lap.
particles slow down.action: That's the point: accelerate particles to study high-energy collisions.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how synchrotrons maintain a fixed orbit.
persistent.action: Key equation: B = mv/qr. For fixed r, B and v must increase together. The name 'synchrotron' means 'synchronized'.

particle_accelerator_applications.name: Particle Accelerator Applications
particle_accelerator_applications.correct: Particle accelerators are used in electron microscopes, mass spectrometers, synchrotron light sources, medical linear accelerators, and high-energy physics research.

only for physics research.fix: Medical: cancer treatment (LINAC), imaging (PET). Industrial: material analysis.
only for physics research.action: List five non-research applications of particle accelerators.

only accelerate electrons.error: Various particles can be accelerated: electrons, protons, ions.
only accelerate electrons.fix: LHC accelerates protons. Medical cyclotrons accelerate various ions.
only accelerate electrons.action: Research: what particles does the Australian Synchrotron accelerate?

always produce collisions.error: Some accelerators produce radiation for imaging or treatment.
always produce collisions.fix: Synchrotron light sources use radiation from bending electrons, not collisions.
always produce collisions.action: Distinguish: colliders (LHC) vs light sources (Australian Synchrotron).

persistent.gap: You have a narrow view of accelerator applications.
persistent.action: Research three accelerator types: medical LINAC, synchrotron light source, particle collider. List what each produces.
